epidemiology: Occurs in 1-2% of all pregnancies. Most commonly in the fallopian tube.
treatment_protocol: Hemodynamically stable: Methotrexate → Unstable or large mass: Surgery

epidemiology: Occurs in 5–8% of pregnancies. More common in first pregnancies and extremes of maternal age.
treatment_protocol: Mild: monitor → Severe: MgSO₄ + delivery at ≥37 weeks

epidemiology: Affects 2–10% of pregnancies. Usually resolves postpartum but increases lifetime risk of type 2 diabetes.
treatment_protocol: Lifestyle → Add insulin if glycemic targets unmet

epidemiology: Occurs in 0.5% of pregnancies. More common with previous cesarean section or uterine surgery.

timeline.symptom: Painless vaginal bleeding in 2nd or 3rd trimester

treatment_protocol: Monitor → Schedule C-section at ~36–37 weeks

epidemiology: Affects 6–10% of reproductive-aged women. Most common endocrine disorder in this group.
treatment_protocol: Lifestyle → OCPs for symptoms → Fertility treatment if desired

epidemiology: Affects ~5% of deliveries. Leading cause of maternal mortality worldwide.
treatment_protocol: IV fluids + uterotonics → Massage → Surgery if unresponsive

epidemiology: Accounts for 3% of gynecologic emergencies. Most common in reproductive-age women.

timeline.symptom: Sudden onset unilateral lower abdominal pain

treatment_protocol: Surgical emergency → Prompt laparoscopy

epidemiology: Affects 6–10% of reproductive-aged women. Common cause of chronic pelvic pain and infertility.
treatment_protocol: Medical management → Surgery if refractory or infertility

epidemiology: Common complication of STIs in women. Affects ~1 million annually in the U.S.
treatment_protocol: Empiric antibiotics → Reassess → Admit if no improvement

epidemiology: Most common pelvic tumor in women. Affects 20–40% of reproductive-aged women.
treatment_protocol: Symptomatic → Medical or surgical depending on fertility plans

epidemiology: Common in reproductive-age women. Often asymptomatic and resolve spontaneously.

definitive: Surgical removal if large or persistent

treatment_protocol: Observe → Surgery if symptomatic or complex

epidemiology: Occurs in up to 20% of all recognized pregnancies in the first trimester.
treatment_protocol: Confirm viability → Expectant management with monitoring

epidemiology: Occurs in 10–15% of early pregnancies. Often follows a threatened miscarriage.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Evacuation of retained products

epidemiology: Occurs after passage of all products of conception. Often follows an inevitable miscarriage.

timeline.symptom: Subsequent cessation of pain and bleeding

treatment_protocol: Confirm complete → Monitor for complications

epidemiology: Occurs in 2–5% of pregnancies. Products of conception remain in the uterus.

definitive: Evacuation of retained products (manual or medical)

treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Evacuate

epidemiology: Often asymptomatic. Diagnosed incidentally during routine ultrasound.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Medical or surgical evacuation

epidemiology: Affects about 6-9% of pregnancies. More common in obese women and those with family history of diabetes.
treatment_protocol: Screen at 24–28 weeks → Monitor glucose → Treat based on severity

epidemiology: Affects 5-10% of pregnancies. More common in first-time pregnancies and multiple gestations.
treatment_protocol: Mild: Monitor → Severe: Admit, control BP, deliver at term

epidemiology: Occurs in 0.5–1% of pregnancies with pre-eclampsia. Leading cause of maternal death.

timeline.symptom: Seizures in a pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia

treatment_protocol: Stabilize mother → Seizure control → Expedite delivery

epidemiology: Occurs in about 0.5% of pregnancies. Risk increases with previous C-sections and multiparity.

timeline.symptom: Painless vaginal bleeding in third trimester

treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Plan C-section at 36–37 weeks

epidemiology: Occurs in 1% of pregnancies. Associated with maternal hypertension and trauma.

definitive: Immediate delivery if unstable or fetal distress

treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Emergency delivery if necessary

epidemiology: Occurs in about 3-5% of deliveries. Leading cause of maternal mortality globally.
treatment_protocol: Assess and stabilize → Identify cause → Treat accordingly

epidemiology: Common postpartum infection, especially after C-section. Incidence is about 1–3% in vaginal deliveries and up to 27% after cesarean.
treatment_protocol: Empiric IV antibiotics → Adjust based on culture

epidemiology: Occurs in 1–5% of women undergoing assisted reproductive technology, especially with hCG use.
treatment_protocol: Classify severity → Supportive care → Admit if severe

epidemiology: Affects 5–10% of women of reproductive age. Common cause of infertility.
treatment_protocol: Lifestyle → Hormonal therapy → Ovulation induction

epidemiology: Accounts for 3% of gynecologic emergencies. Most common in reproductive-age women.

timeline.symptom: Sudden onset unilateral lower abdominal pain

treatment_protocol: Urgent surgery to preserve ovarian function

epidemiology: Occurs in about 1 in 1000 pregnancies. More common in extremes of reproductive age.

emergency_markers: High β-hCG with no fetal parts

treatment_protocol: Evacuation → Monitor β-hCG → Chemotherapy if persistent

epidemiology: Rare malignant trophoblastic tumor. Can follow molar pregnancy, abortion, or normal delivery.
treatment_protocol: Stage disease → Start chemo → Monitor β-hCG

epidemiology: Occurs in 1 in 100 pregnancies. Often detected in the second trimester.

emergency_markers: Bulging membranes in the absence of contractions

treatment_protocol: Identify risk → Offer cerclage before 24 weeks

epidemiology: Affects 75% of women at least once. More frequent in pregnancy, diabetes, and antibiotic use.
treatment_protocol: Single dose or 7-day topical regimen depending on severity

epidemiology: Occurs mainly after uterine surgeries such as D&C. Common in women with amenorrhea after surgery.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose via hysteroscopy → Surgical lysis → Prevent recurrence

epidemiology: Affects up to 70% of women by age 50. More common in African descent and women in reproductive age.
treatment_protocol: Medical therapy → Conservative surgery → Hysterectomy if indicated

epidemiology: Occurs in 20–35% of women, typically in those aged 35–50 years. Often coexists with fibroids or endometriosis.
treatment_protocol: Trial medical therapy → Surgery if refractory

epidemiology: Affects 1% of women under 40. Can be idiopathic or related to autoimmune or genetic causes.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start HRT → Monitor bone and cardiovascular health

epidemiology: Affects 1 million women annually in the US. Common in sexually active women <25 years.

definitive: IV or oral antibiotics per CDC guidelines

treatment_protocol: Empiric antibiotics → Monitor → Admit if severe

epidemiology: Affects up to 50% of parous women. Risk increases with age and vaginal delivery.
treatment_protocol: Assess severity → Conservative or surgical treatment

epidemiology: Iatrogenic complication of ovulation induction. Occurs in 1-5% of women undergoing IVF.
treatment_protocol: Monitor → Hydration → Hospitalize if severe

epidemiology: Postpartum hypopituitarism due to severe blood loss during delivery. Rare in developed countries.
treatment_protocol: Hormone replacement as per deficiencies

epidemiology: Common gynecologic emergency, especially in reproductive-age women. Often involves cyst >5cm.
treatment_protocol: Emergency laparoscopy for detorsion

epidemiology: Common precancerous lesion detected via Pap smear. Linked to HPV 16 and 18.
treatment_protocol: Screen → Biopsy → Ablation or excision depending on grade

epidemiology: One of the leading causes of gynecologic cancer death. Peak incidence post-menopause.
treatment_protocol: Stage disease → Surgery → Adjuvant chemotherapy

epidemiology: Affects 3–7% of pregnancies. Higher incidence in low-resource settings.

emergency_markers: Absent or reversed umbilical artery flow

definitive: Early delivery if deterioration or term reached

treatment_protocol: Monitor growth and Dopplers → Plan delivery accordingly

epidemiology: Affects 2–10% of pregnancies globally. Risk increases with maternal age and BMI.
treatment_protocol: Screen → Diet/exercise → Start insulin if required

epidemiology: Leading cause of maternal mortality worldwide. Defined as blood loss >500ml (vaginal) or >1000ml (C-section).
treatment_protocol: A→B→C resuscitation → Uterotonics → Escalate to surgery

epidemiology: Occurs in 1–2% of term deliveries and up to 25% of preterm births.
treatment_protocol: Antibiotics → Expedite delivery → Monitor neonate

epidemiology: Precursor to endometrial cancer. Common in postmenopausal women with unopposed estrogen exposure.
treatment_protocol: Biopsy to confirm → Progestins or surgery depending on type

epidemiology: Occurs in about 10% of all pregnancies. Leading cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality.

emergency_markers: Cervical change with contractions before 37 weeks

treatment_protocol: Identify → Delay labor if safe → Administer corticosteroids

epidemiology: Rare; typically occurs after uterine surgeries like D&C. Associated with infertility and amenorrhea.
treatment_protocol: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis → Hormonal therapy

epidemiology: 1 in 1000 pregnancies in developed countries; more common in Asia and low-resource areas.
treatment_protocol: Evacuation → Monitor hCG → Chemotherapy if persistent

epidemiology: Affects 1 million women per year in the US. Frequently caused by Chlamydia or Gonorrhea.
treatment_protocol: Antibiotics (IM/IV then oral) → Reassess in 48–72 hours

epidemiology: Chronic inflammatory skin condition primarily affecting postmenopausal women. Prevalence is underreported.
treatment_protocol: Steroid ointment daily → Maintenance therapy

epidemiology: Common in women of reproductive age; most are functional and benign.

emergency_markers: Severe acute pain suggesting torsion or rupture

definitive: Surgical removal if persistent or suspicious

treatment_protocol: Monitor → Repeat imaging → Surgery if indicated

epidemiology: Affects 20–30% of women in reproductive age. Often coexists with fibroids or endometriosis.
treatment_protocol: Medical therapy → Hysterectomy if unresponsive

epidemiology: Fourth most common cancer in women worldwide. Strongly linked to persistent HPV infection.

definitive: Surgery or chemoradiation depending on stage

treatment_protocol: Staging → Radical hysterectomy or chemoradiation

epidemiology: Affects 75% of women at least once in their life. Common in pregnancy, diabetes, antibiotic use.
treatment_protocol: Topical or oral antifungals → Maintenance for recurrent

epidemiology: Common in women of reproductive age. Occurs when duct becomes blocked, forming fluid-filled swelling.

emergency_markers: Severe pain and swelling suggesting abscess

treatment_protocol: Drain if symptomatic → Marsupialization if recurrent
